awd_titl_txt: BMES 2022 Annual Meeting “Embracing Inclusion to Advance Innovation in Healthcare and Education”; San Antonio, Texas; 12-15 October 2022.
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) Annual meeting in San Antonio, Texas, 12-15 October 2022. The BMES Annual Meeting serves as the premier event for scientific sharing and dissemination amongst biomedical engineers in the academic, industry and educational sectors. Beyond research and educational presentations, the mission of the 2022 BMES annual meeting is to provide opportunities for building strategic networks, promoting career development and advancement, sharing ideas, recognizing and promoting talent, developing and promoting professional excellence, and broadening the participation of underserved and underrepresented groups. This award will provide critical support to enhance diversity of participants at the BMES Annual Meeting and advance inclusion and promote success in continuing in the Biomedical engineering (BME) educational pathway and profession.  

The 2022 BMES meeting will focus on the future to showcase innovative developments in research and education. The theme of this meeting is equity issues in healthcare and education stemming from racial and socioeconomic diversity, gender and sexual orientation, and disabilities. The meeting will connect research and education communities to stimulate new strategies to advance healthcare. The meeting will be highlighted by exciting plenary speakers, research sessions, workshops, and outreach programs that will provide valuable information and opportunities to engage with the biomedical engineering community. There will be activities at the 2022 Annual Meeting to increase participation from underrepresented minority engineering groups across multiple stages, including high school students, community college students, undergraduate, and graduate students, postdoctoral trainees and early career faculty and professionals. This award will support two merit-based awards (Student Chapter Awards), a High School Expo, and online streaming fee waivers for underserved individuals. These activities will help ensure value to a broader representation of BME Annual Meeting attendees and encourage diverse perspectives and innovative thinking in planning and evaluation of meeting activities. This broader representation at the BMES Annual Meeting will help expand participation of underrepresented groups in both BME and in engineering, and will contribute to engaging the future generation of biomedical engineers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2022 Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) Annual Meeting was held in San Antonio, Texas, from October 12-15, 2022. The total number of participants increased from the prior year to 4,207, with 2,441 students (58%), 762 professionals (18%), and 281 early career / postdoctoral (7%). The meeting was attended by 2,225 people who identified as female (53% of participants), 2,177 attendees who did not identify as white (52% of attendees), and 423 LGBTQIA+ self-identified attendees (10% of attendees). BMES also hosted 17 attendees who identified as needing accommodation under the American Disabilities Act. The enduring appeal of the conference reflects the increasing interest and enthusiasm within the biomedical engineering community, solidifying the BMES Annual Meeting as a crucial platform that unites leading researchers, universities, and industry professionals.

 

At the 2022 BMES Annual Meeting, the NSF conference award funds supported 45 participants. This included five (5) merit-based Student Chapter Awards (enabling 10 students to attend the meeting). The five Student Chapter Awards funded by the grant were 1) Outstanding Outreach Program Award for those chapters who demonstrated leadership in community outreach, service, and STEM volunteerism; 2) Outstanding Mentoring Program Award for chapters who demonstrated leadership in mentorship with special consideration for the collegiate student chapters who mentor high school student chapters in a tangible way; 3) Outstanding Societal Impact Award for to those chapters who endeavored to highlight and solve a real-world medical problem within their immediate community; 4) Outstanding Achievement Award given in recognition of exceptional leadership and immeasurable growth to chapters who demonstrated they lead the field in social activities, fundraising, mentorship, community outreach, and industry partnership; and 5) Commendable Achievement Award for the chapter who demonstrated unlimited opportunities for growth and success and exhibited the ability to lead in many different facets of biomedical engineering.

 

Funds were also used to bring in underrepresented high school students and expose them to BMES and BME by supporting a High School Expo and Poster Competition Program at the Annual Meeting. The High School Expo drew in 20 underrepresented high school students and chaperones from San Antonio area high schools and beyond to participate in the Annual Meeting on Thursday, October 13, 2022. The Expo included an orientation to discuss what the day would entail and gave the students and their chaperones the chance to make connections with student chapter members available to answer questions, share experiences and help guide them through the meeting as mentors. NSF funds supported eight (8) students and six (6) chaperones to participate in the program, which gave students the chance to participate in the BMES State of Society and Pritzker Distinguished Lecture Award, attend and present posters, visit exhibitor booths, attend the Diversity Award Lecture, and participate in a variety of student and early career sessions.

 

Lastly, the grant funds supported online conference streaming fee waivers for 21 underserved individuals to participate in the meeting. The waivers enabled participants to stream plenary sessions, diversity lunches, and receptions to increase diversity and equitable access to biomedical engineering research.

The NSF conference grant funds facilitated the participation of students and professionals in various activities, offering opportunities to support learning for everyone involved. Broadening the participation of underserved and underrepresented groups through the award increased opportunities for advancing inclusion in mentoring, networking, career advancement, learning of educational and professional opportunities, and development of professional excellence among students, academics, and industry professionals at a level that participants may not otherwise have had the opportunity to experience. The conference funding helped bring value to a broader representation of BMES Annual Meeting attendees and encouraged diverse perspectives and innovative thinking in planning and evaluation of meeting activities. By increasing exposure and engagement of underserved and underrepresented groups in BME and activities at the meeting, these efforts contributed to broader impacts supporting diversity and awareness of biomedical engineering as a professional discipline and promoting success in continuing the biomedical engineering educational pathway and profession.
